Award.AbstractNarration:
Hyperkahler manifolds arise in many different areas of high energy theoretical physics, for example as spaces parametrizing Yang-Mills instantons, magnetic monopoles, and Higgs fields. In their algebro-geometric manifestation, hyperkahler manifolds appear as holomorphic symplectic manifolds. Fibrations on holomorphic symplectic manifolds are known as Lagrangian fibrations, since the fibers must be Lagrangian with respect to the holomorphic symplectic structure. In addition, the generic fibres must be abelian varieties, and Lagrangian fibrations may be viewed as higher-dimensional analogues of elliptic K3 surfaces. The Hitchin system is a celebrated non-compact example. In this project the P.I. will study the classification of (compact) Lagrangian fibrations. The goals are to classify Lagrangian fibrations in some particular cases: when the fibers are Jacobians of curves or principally polarized, when the fibration is locally isotrivial, in dimension four (abelian surfaces as fibers). The P.I. will also explore new constructions of Lagrangian fibrations, and address the question of finiteness of deformation classes.

This project will develop some particular kinds of geometry that are known to arise in theoretical physics, particularly in quantum field theory and string theory. The main focus will be on hyperkahler geometry, a class of spaces admitting Ricci-flat metrics, i.e., solutions to Einstein's equations in a vacuum. The P.I. will also study generalized complex geometry, which was invented by mathematicians to bridge complex and symplectic geometry, on which type IIA and IIB string theory are based, and to help unravel the Mirror Symmetry phenomenon predicted by string theorists. In short, these are all innovative new kinds of geometry developed largely in response to the demands of theoretical physicists, but also of inherent mathematical interest. The P.I. will actively promote the exchange of ideas between mathematicians and physicists by organizing and participating in cross-disciplinary conferences and workshops, and is also involved in the training of graduate students in these topics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many people are familiar with complex numbers: they are a two-dimensional number system because a complex number x+iy requires two real numbers x and y to describe it. The quaternions are a four-dimensional number system discovered in the mid-19th century. They were used to describe kinematics and electromagnetism before being superseded by descriptions in terms of vectors. The quaternions enjoyed a resurgence in the late 20th, because of their effectiveness in describing spatial relations in computer graphics, robotics, control theory, and signal processing. In particular, multiplication in the quaternions provides an efficient way to describe rotations in space. The quaternions can also be used to describe certain higher-dimensional curved spaces known as hyperkahler manifolds. These spaces frequently arise as state-spaces in high-energy physics models, the spaces parametrizing all possible configurations of particles/fields/strings in quantum field theory and string theory. A particularly famous example is the space of Higgs bundles, the mathematical counterparts of the Higgs boson (the last elementary particle of the Standard Model of particle physics, whose existence was recently verified at CERN's Large Hadron Collider). Hyperkahler manifolds are also special examples of solutions to the Einstein vacuum equations, the fundamental equations that determine the curvature of space-time in general relativity.

With the support of this award, Justin Sawon investigated certain fibered structures on hyperkahler manifolds, known as Lagrangian fibrations. A fibration is simply a partition of a geometric space into identical pieces, like the strands in a spaghetti squash or the layers of pastry in a mille-feuille; the Lagrangian condition is an additional constraint, implying that the fibers be half-dimensional. Sawon established a finiteness result, limiting the number of hyperkahler manifolds admitting Lagrangian fibrations. He classified such fibrations when the fibers adhere to certain stricter restrictions. He also constructed new examples of singular hyperkahler spaces admitting fibrations (singularities in the space-time background are an acceptable part of string theory; indeed they lead to various interesting phenomena). The existence of Lagrangian fibrations provides one of the key explanations for Mirror Symmetry, which relates the type IIA and IIB models of supersymmetric string theory. This is important because there should not exist independent models of string theory: they should only be different mathematical descriptions of the same underlying physics. Sawon's work advances our mathematical understanding of the spaces underlying string theory and their geometric properties, particularly those properties that are valuable for developing relations between different physical models.

During the award period, Sawon mentored three honors student, two masters students, and two PhD students, including one female (an underrepresented group in the mathematical sciences) who is now in a tenure-track position as a mathematics professor. Sawon was involved in other outreach programs designed to promote mathematics among underrepresented groups; for example, as part of Project Uplift he led an experiential learning program for high school students from diverse backgrounds in summer 2015. Sawon organized a total of four international workshops, two with a particular emphasis on showcasing the work of junior mathematicians (postdoctoral researchers), and one that brought together mathematicians and theoretical physicists with a common interest in hyperkahler geometry. Sawon also delivered over 30 invited lectures at research seminars, workshops, and conferences (many of them international). He is grateful for the NSF funding that supported these activities.
